Key Arguments: The legislation risks infringing on freedom of speech, which is a fundamental pillar of democracy.
Definitions of misinformation and disinformation can be subjective and may lead to biases or unintended consequences.
There is concern over who determines what constitutes misinformation and the potential for censorship.
The effectiveness of the legislation is questioned, suggesting that a comprehensive approach beyond legislation is needed.
The legislation should align with international human rights standards and not disproportionately burden online platforms.
Information deemed misinformation today may later be proven true, raising concerns about how such cases will be managed.
Notable Quotes: The introduction of this legislation provides the government with the power to effectively discard freedom of speech within our society.
Should this legislation be introduced, would Australia remain to be considered as a democratic society?
In conclusion, I completely disagree with the introduction of any legislation that censors information available to the Australian people and impedes on their freedom of speech.
